questions.text: MESS Score used in deciding about limb salvage includes:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above

Highyeild:

Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) and its modifications are useful in deciding about limb salvage. Extensive tissue loss, neurovascular damage and loss of long fragments of bone are traditional indications for amputation. Components Patient’s Age Limb Ischemia Vascular Status Absorbed Energy A score of 7 or higher consistently predicted the need for amputation, whereas all limbs with initial scores of 6 or less remained viable in the long term A MESS should be calculated for each patient but should be used with caution as a guideline to supplement the clinical findings.

questions.text: Primary Survey of a Traumatic Patient follows cABCDE.'c' and 'C' respectively stand for
questions.correct_answer: C. Exsanguinating external haemorrhage and circulation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Exsanguinating external haemorrhage and circulation Primary Survey : The primary survey aims to identify and manage the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first and follows cABCDE . The role of the trauma team is to apply the principles of Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) to rapidly identify and treat life-threatening injuries during the primary survey AIRWAY WITH CERVICAL SPINE PROTECTION: Assess airway patency : If not patent : Chin lift/jaw thrust Clear airway from foreign body Insert oropharyngeal/nasopharyngeal airway Establish a definitive airway. BREATHING ( VENTILATION AND OXYGENATION ): Assess breathing, Rate and depth Percuss chest Auscultate chest Administer oxygen Attach pulse oximeter for monitoring the spo2 of the patient. If abnormal breathing is detected, management: Ventilate the patient if required. Alleviate tension pneumothorax Seal open pneumothorax. CIRCULATION WITH HEMORRHAGIC CONTROL: Assess circulation, Identify external haemorrhage Pulse BP Skin colour Identify potential internal haemorrhage. If the abnormality is detected: Apply direct pressure over the external bleeding point. Insert 2 large bore iv canula. Simultaneously obtain blood for blood transfusion and cross match Initiate iv fluids. Consider the potential need for operative management. DISABILITY: Assess consciousness Use GCS score. Assess pupils Size/ equality/ reaction. EXPOSURE / ENVIRONMENT: Completely undress the patient but prevent hypothermia. Anterior and posterior nasal packing should be done to prevent nasal bleeding. Resuscitation of patients with hypovolemic shock begins by making the airway secure by ensuring proper ventilation and oxygen therapy. External bleeding is done by the application of pressure and surgical control. Immediately life-threatening pulmonary injuries should be early detected and treated as soon as possible. Large bore iv cannula to prevent hypovolemic shock The chest X-ray is of utmost importance in cases with pulmonary injuries. Trauma resuscitation (1:1:1) packed cells, plasma, and platelets are used in this ratio. Because most patients do not require more than 6 units of PRBCs, most do not receive FFP. For patients who require more units of PRBCs, 7-12 units of PRBCs should be administered along with 6 units of FFP and 1 unit of apheresis platelets. Preferably, FFP and platelets should be transfused first, before the next 6 units of PRBCs are transfused.

Extraedge:

The Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) system delineates an order of priorities defned by ABCD; that is, airway, breathing, circulation and disability (neurology). This hierarchy of priorities is based on the ‘time dependence’ principle. In such settings, time is critical, so the normal history and physical investigations are not performed during the ATLS primary survey, but the primary focus is on detecting and identifying individual problems , ranking them in order of priority and dealing with them efectively and efciently in their appropriate timeframes.

questions.text: A person met with an RTA and was brought to the ER. On examination he was conscious and BP- 100/60 mmHg, PR-140 / min and was managed conservatively first according to the ATLS protocol. He was given blood and IV fluids too. After the patient become stable, he was sent for radiological investigations where the lower pole of the spleen revealed lacerations along with hemoperitoneum. The next step in management would be?

options.label: A
options.text: Exploring the patient followed by excision of the lower pole of the spleen

options.label: B
options.text: Exploring the patient followed by splenectomy

options.label: D
options.text: Continuation of conservative management under a close monitoring system and subsequent surgery if further indicated

questions.correct_answer: D. Continuation of conservative management under a close monitoring system and subsequent surgery if further indicated
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Continuation of conservative management under a close monitoring system and subsequent surgery if further indicated Since the patient is stable he can be considered for conservative management under close monitoring and if any derangement occurs with the patient's status he has to be planned for exploration.

Highyeild:

The spleen is the most commonly injured intra-abdominal organ followed by the liver . Splenic rupture should be considered in any case of blunt abdominal trauma , particularly when the injury occurs to the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. Iatrogenic injury to the spleen remains a frequent complication of any surgical procedure, particularly those in the left upper quadrant when adhesions are present .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A: Exploring the patient is not necessary as the patient is stable and he responds well to conservative management. Surgery proceeds if the conservative management doesn’t respond well. Option: B: Exploring the patient is not necessary as the patient is stable and he responds well to conservative management Option: C: If the conservative management doesn’t respond well then the patient should be considered for splenorrhaphy after exploration.

questions.text: A 23- year- old male is admitted to the ER with RTA. He was conscious on admission and hemodynamically stable too. On examination, his vitals were BP- 110/70 mmHg, PR-79/ min and RR- 28 / min. He was managed according to the ATLS guidelines. On per abdominal examination, abdominal tenderness and guarding were present. On CT it was found that 1 cm deep lacerations were in the left lobe of the liver extending from the dome more than halfway through the parenchyma. What is the appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Abdominal exploration and packing of hepatic wounds

options.label: B
options.text: Abdominal exploration and ligation of left hepatic artery

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Conservative management Stable and left lobe laceration = no organ injury/bleeding therefore managed conservatively. Mechanism of blunt hepatic trauma: compression with direct parenchymal damage and shearing forces. which tear hepatic tissue and disrupt vascular and ligamentous attachments. Most liver injuries involve segments 6,7 and 8. Mostly the bleeding seen in hepatic injuries is venous, and therefore low pressure, tamponade is readily performed.

Highyeild:

Liver Trauma: Liver injury due to blunt or penetrating abdominal trauma is second in frequency only to that of the spleen. Blunt injury produces contusion, laceration and avulsion, often associated with splenic, mesenteric or renal injuries. (Common & has high Mortality) Penetrating injuries , including stab and gunshot wounds , are often associated with chest or pericardial involvement. Complications: Intrahepatic haematoma Liver abscess Bile collection Biliary fistula Haemobilia Ascites Biliary strictures Intra-abdominal collections Hepatic artery aneurysm Arteriovenous fistula Arterio Biliary fistula Liver failure Diagnosis: The liver is an extremely well-vascularised organ and blood loss is the major early complication following injury A high index of suspicion is essential with any chest or upper abdominal stab wound, especially where significant blood loss is obvious . Severe crushing injuries to the lower chest or upper abdomen frequently result in rib fractures, haemothorax and splenic and/or liver injury. Penetrating injuries are frequently associated with massive, continued blood loss and coagulopathies ; transfer to the operating theatre should occur while blood products are obtained and resuscitation continues. Focused assessment sonography in trauma (FAST) performed by an experienced operator will identify free intraperitoneal fluid. In haemodynamically unstable patients with penetrating wounds, a laparotomy and/or thoracotomy is indicated once active resuscitation has commenced In haemodynamically stable patients , an urgent contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest and abdomen is performed to look for parenchymal injury and concomitant damage to other thoracic or abdominal organs

questions.text: A patient of a road traffic accident comes to your centre with a head injury. Your centre has a CT scan machine but no neurosurgeon. The treating doctor stabilises the patient on the primary survey. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Refer the patient to a higher centre after getting a CT head

options.label: B
options.text: Refer the patient to a higher centre without getting a CT head

options.label: C
options.text: Do a CT head and manage the patient at your centre

questions.correct_answer: B. Refer the patient to a higher centre without getting a CT head
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Refer the patient to a higher centre without getting a CT head The purpose of the primary survey is to detect and simultaneously treat immediate life-threatening injuries. After the primary survey, if adequate treatment options for the secondary survey and definitive management of the patient are not available, the patient must be referred to a higher centre without any further workup.

Highyeild:

Trauma Assessment & Management: Primary Survey: The primary survey aims to identify and manage the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first and follows cABCDE . The role of the trauma team is to apply the principles of Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) to rapidly identify and treat life-threatening injuries during the primary survey cABCDE. c – Control of massive external haemorrhage A – Airway with cervical spine protection B – Breathing and ventilation C – Circulation and haemorrhage control D – Disability E – Exposure Tranexamic acid: An Antifibrinolytic drug that reduces the risk of mortality from bleeding in both blunt and penetrating trauma . One gram is given intravenously over 10 minutes , followed by a further 1-g dose over 8 hours Secondary Survey: ATLS defines the secondary survey as a thorough head-to-toe examination and patient history. This is often performed immediately after the primary survey in patients who are stable and not requiring emergent intervention ETC – Early Total Care ETC describes the definitive management of a patient’s injuries within 36 hours of injury after a period of initial resuscitation DCS – Damage Control Surgery DCS describes simultaneous resuscitation with early rapid life and limb-saving surgery. Time-consuming definitive surgery is deferred until the patient’s physiological status allows

Since a neurosurgeon is not available at the centre, getting a CT scan of the head is not a rational option as the diagnostic workup and treatment plan must be made by the treating neurosurgeon only. Option: C. In the absence of a qualified neurosurgeon, a patient with a head injury must not be treated by those not qualified for it. Option: D. Wait and watch is not a good option as there may be an underlying injury to the skull or brain.

questions.text: You have come out on a morning stroll as per your daily routine. You suddenly spot two goons attacking a woman with wooden sticks on her face and chest, and stealing her belongings. You run to the scene. What is the first thing you would do in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ensure scene safety The first thing to do at the site of finding a patient of trauma is to ensure scene safety to ensure the safety of self. In this case, you must ensure that there is no further danger to the woman or you.

Highyeild:

Role of a Trauma Team: Allows the simultaneous and efficient application of ATLS principles to rapidly identify and treat life-threatening pathologies Should be led by the most senior clinician The most senior clinicians from each speciality should attend ‘code red trauma calls’ The team leader should be trying constantly to anticipate the next move

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Calling for help isn’t the first step when you spot a patient with trauma. First, you must ensure scene safety, then check the response of the patient and then call for help Option: B. Checking the response of the woman is the next step after ensuring scene safety Option: D. Finally after calling for help, you should talk to the patient. If the patient can talk, it indicates that the airway of the patient is fine.

Solution:

Grey Two wide-bore IV cannulae are preferred and an antecubital vein is preferred for the same. 16 G cannula or the grey cannula is the best cannula for this purpose.

questions.text: A young athlete who had met with a car accident was brought to the emergency room with bleeding from the lower extremities. Which of the following statement is false about haemorrhagic shock?

options.label: A
options.text: Definitive control of haemorrhage and restoration of adequate circulating volume are the goals of treating haemorrhagic shock.

options.label: B
options.text: The most effective way of restoring adequate cardiac output, end-organ perfusion, and tissue oxygenation is to restore venous return to normal by initiating a massive transfusion protocol.

options.label: C
options.text: Any injured patient who is cool to the touch and is tachycardic should be considered to be in shock.

options.label: D
options.text: Massive blood loss may produce only a slight decrease in initial haematocrit.

questions.correct_answer: B. The most effective way of restoring adequate cardiac output, end-organ perfusion, and tissue oxygenation is to restore venous return to normal by initiating a massive transfusion protocol.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The most effective way of restoring adequate cardiac output, end-organ perfusion, and tissue oxygenation is to restore venous return to normal by initiating a massive transfusion protocol. The most effective way of restoring adequate cardiac output, end-organ perfusion, and tissue oxygenation is to restore venous return to normal by locating and stopping the source of bleeding. Volume repletion will allow recovery from the shock state only when the bleeding has stopped.

Highyeild:

SHOCK: Shock is a systemic state of low tissue perfusion that is inadequate for normal cellular respiration . With insufficient delivery of oxygen and glucose, cells switch from aerobic to anaerobic metabolism. If perfusion is not restored in a timely fashion, cell death ensues . Classification Of Shock: Hemorrhagic/hypovolemic shock (due to reduced circulating volume) Causes: Non-Haemorrhagic Poor fluid intake (dehydration), Excessive fluid loss due to vomiting, Diarrhoea, urinary loss (e.g. diabetes), Evaporation or ‘third spacing’, where fluid is lost into the gastrointestinal tract and interstitial spaces , for example in a bowel obstruction or pancreatitis. Haemorrhagic Types: Revealed Haemorrhage (External Haemorrhage) Eg. exsanguination from an open arterial wound Concealed Haemorrhage (Within the Body Cavity) Eg. occult gastrointestinal bleeding A primary haemorrhage is a haemorrhage occurring immediately as a result of an injury (or surgery) . Reactionary haemorrhage is delayed haemorrhage (within 24 hours) and is usually due to the dislodgement of a clot by resuscitation, normalisation of blood pressure and vasodilatation. Reactionary haemorrhage may also be due to technical failures, such as slippage of a ligature. Secondary haemorrhage is due to sloughing of the wall of a vessel. It usually occurs 7–14 days after injury and is precipitated by factors such as infection, pressure necrosis (such as from a drain) or malignancy. Classification: Traditional classification of haemorrhagic shock Class 1 2 3 4 Blood volume lost as percentage of total <15% 15-30 30-40% 40% Haemorrhage Resuscitation Identify Haemorrhage Damage Control Resuscitation Principles rapid haemorrhage control permissive hypotension avoiding dilutional coagulopathy treating existing coagulation deficits

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Definitive control of haemorrhage and restoration of adequate circulating volume are the goals of treating haemorrhagic shock. We should maintain the vitals of the patient. Option: C. Any injured patient who is cool to touch and is tachycardic should be considered to be in shock. Option: D. Massive blood loss may produce only a slight decrease in initial haematocrit or haemoglobin concentration.

questions.text: Amongst the components of the primary survey, E stands for Exposure and Environmental control. Which of the following statement is true regarding this?

options.label: A
options.text: Completely undress the patient during the primary survey

options.label: B
options.text: After completing the assessment, cover the patient with warm blankets / external warming device

options.label: C
options.text: Administer warm intravenous fluids, and maintain a warm environment

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Exposure and Environment control: During the primary survey, completely undress the patient, usually by cutting off his/her garments to facilitate a thorough examination and assessment because there can be some hidden injuries which can be seen after adequate exposure. After completing the assessment, cover the patient with warm blankets or an external warming device to prevent him or her from developing hypothermia in the trauma-receiving area. Warm intravenous fluids before infusing them, and maintain a warm environment. Hypothermia can be present when the patient arrives, or it may develop quickly in the emergency room if the patient is uncovered and undergoes rapid administration of room-temperature fluids or refrigerated blood. Because hypothermia is a potentially lethal complication in injured patients, take aggressive measures to prevent the loss of body heat and restore body temperature to normal.

questions.text: A 30-year-old driver was brought to you in casualty, who has sustained multiple injuries all over the body. Pulse- 120/min, BP – 90/60 mm Hg, Spo2 – 92%, RR – 24/min, unresponsive to commands (GSC: 8/15). A diagnosis of simple pneumothorax is made. What is the next most appropriate step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Intubate and provide positive pressure ventilation

questions.correct_answer: C. Chest decompression with tube insertion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chest decompression with tube insertion Airway patency alone does not ensure adequate ventilation. Adequate gas exchange is required to maximize oxygenation and carbon dioxide elimination. Ventilation requires the adequate function of the lungs, chest wall, and diaphragm; therefore, clinicians must rapidly examine and evaluate each component. Injuries that significantly impair ventilation in the short term include tension pneumothorax, massive haemothorax, open pneumothorax, and tracheal or bronchial injuries. These injuries should be identified during the primary survey and often require immediate attention to ensure effective ventilation. Because a tension pneumothorax compromises ventilation and circulation dramatically and acutely, chest decompression should follow immediately when suspected by clinical evaluation. Simple pneumothorax, simple haemothorax, fractured ribs, flail chest, and pulmonary contusion can compromise ventilation to a lesser degree and are usually identified during the secondary survey. A simple pneumothorax can be converted to a tension pneumothorax when a patient is intubated and positive pressure ventilation is provided before decompressing the pneumothorax with a chest tube Whereas Tension pneumothorax can be associated with hemodynamic imbalance.

Highyeild:

Pnuemothorax: Pneumothorax is the presence of air outside the lung, within the pleural space Types: Spontaneous Primary (Common among young men) It is due to leaks from small blebs, vesicles or bullae, which may become pedunculated, typically at the apex of the upper lobe or on the upper border of the lower or middle lobes. Secondary This occurs when the visceral pleura leaks as part of underlying lung disease; any disease that involves the pleura may cause pneumothorax, including tuberculosis, any cavitating lung disease and necrosing tumour Tension pneumothorax : When (independent of aetiology) there is a build-up of positive pressure within the hemithorax, to the extent that the lung is completely collapsed, the diaphragm is fattened, the mediastinum is distorted and, eventually, the venous return to the heart is compromised. Management Surgical Management : VATS - Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery Thoracotomy - Open Procedure

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. A simple pneumothorax can be converted to a tension pneumothorax when a patient is intubated and positive pressure ventilation is provided before decompressing the pneumothorax with a chest tube Option: B. Not Indicated before chest decompression Option: D. Not Indicated before chest decompression

questions.text: As per ATLS protocols which of the following statement is not false

options.label: A
options.text: Four persons are needed to perform log rolling.

options.label: B
options.text: Three persons are needed to perform helmet removal.

options.label: C
options.text: One person is needed to perform a chin lift, Jaw thrust manoeuvres.

questions.correct_answer: A. Four persons are needed to perform log rolling.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Four persons are needed to perform log rolling. At least four people are needed for logrolling a patient to remove a spine board and/or examine the back.

Highyeild:

The log roll manoeuvre is performed to evaluate the patient’s spine and remove the long spine board while limiting spinal movement. One person stands at the patient’s head to control the head and c-spine, and two are along the patient’s sides to control the body and extremities. As the patient is rolled, three people maintain alignment of the spine while the fourth person removes the board and examines the back. Once the board is removed, three people return the patient to the supine position while maintaining the alignment of the spine. Per rectum, the examination is also performed during this time only In case 5 people are not available then, a total of 4 persons are mandatory .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option B : Removing a helmet properly is a two-person procedur e. While one person restricts the movement of the cervical spine, the second person expands the helmet laterally. The second person then removes the helmet, while ensuring that the helmet clears the nose and occiput. After the helmet is removed, the first person supports the weight of the patient’s head and the second person takes over the restriction of cervical spine motion. Option C : In patients who have a decreased level of consciousness, the tongue can fall backwards and obstruct the hypopharynx. To readily correct this form of obstruction, healthcare providers use chin-lift or jaw-thrust manoeuvers. Manoeuvers used to establish an airway can produce or aggravate the c-spine injury, so restriction of cervical spinal motion by other personnel is mandatory during these procedures . Management of the cervical spine is the most important step after trauma. Chin lift manoeuvre : The chin-lift manoeuvre is performed by placing the fingers of one hand under the mandible and then gently lifting it upward to bring the chin anterior. With the thumb of the same hand, lightly depress the lower lip to open the mouth. The thumb also may be placed behind the lower incisors while simultaneously lifting the chin gently. Do not hyperextend the neck while employing the chin-lift manoeuvre. Jaw Thrust manoeuvre : To perform a jaw thrust manoeuvre, grasp the angles of the mandibles with a hand on each side and then displace the mandible forward. When used with the facemask of a bag-mask device, this manoeuvre can result in a good seal and adequate ventilation. As in the chin-lift manoeuver, be careful not to extend the patient’s neck.

Extraedge:

If patients need to be moved during their primary survey, such as when moving onto the CT scanning gantry, a 20° roll with inline spinal stabilisation should be used Modern ‘scoop stretchers’ mean that there is no requirement to roll any patient more than 20° until a pelvic fracture has been excluded
